snippet: An examination of the system’s problems reveals an investment strategy that has failed to keep up with growing costs, and a governing structure that often permits politics to intrude.
abstract: Examination of New York City's pension system’s problems reveals an investment strategy that has failed to keep up with growing costs, hampered by an antiquated and inefficient governing structure that often permits politics to intrude on decisions; assets are falling further behind obligations, troubling trend that could eventually ripple across entire city budget, but which has received little attention so far under Mayor Bill de Blasio.

byline.original: By DAVID W. CHEN and MARY WILLIAMS WALSH

lead_paragraph: An examination of the system’s problems reveals an investment strategy that has failed to keep up with growing costs, and a governing structure that often permits politics to intrude.

headline.main: New York City Pension System Is Strained by Costs and Politics
headline.print_headline: City’s System for Pensions Shows Strain

keywords.value: New York City Employees' Retirement System
keywords.name: organizations
